Capital of the Mediterranean Sea, it was founded about 3000 years ago by the Phoenicians. 
Panormus is the name given to the city by Greeks and Romans, and it means "all port". 
Thanks to his position, between two rivers and the sea, Palermo has always enjoyed from the natural richness of the land as well as the one coming from the water. 
Since the ancient era, Palermo has been visited and populated by some of the most important cultures of the known world, and walking through the city today is like traveling through time, from the prehistorical paintings in the caves of the Addaura to the arab-norman Palazzo Reale, right until the Neoclassic and modern buildings of Via Roma. 
There's a lot to see and many things you shouldn't miss, so in this app I will suggest you 5 things you have to do if you're visiting Palermo and want to really know the heart of the city.
Have fun and enjoy your stay!
Take a walk down the Cassaro

It\'s the most ancient street of the city, and its name comes from the arabic al Qasr, which means \"fortified\" since it was the main street inside the city walls (today it\'s called Corso Vittorio Emanuele, in honor of the famous Italian king). \nIt\'s a straight line that connects Porta Nuova to Porta Felice and if walked from south to north, it connects the city to the sea. \nThe name Cassaro also extends to all the historical city centre, which is surrounded by the ancent city walls and contains all the most important building of the political and clerical power, along with some of the most beautiful churches in all Europe, and many important commercial activities.

Take a whole day to explore each street and alley, visit every church and buy typical artisanal products from the colorful shops, and don\'t forget to stop by Quattro Canti, the famous crossing between Corso Vittorio and via Maqueda.

One of the many jewels of Palermo, since 2015 la Cattedrale is UNESCO World Heritage, and the most visited monument of the city. It was built during the Middle Age, after the Christians conquered back the city from the Arabs, in the area where once stood a Mosque and a Byzantine basilica before that. \nThe Cathedral is the most evident example of the Arab-Norman style, a mix of the northern european taste of the Royal families and the excellent building skills of the Arabs who worked at their courts. \nThe interior has undergone many renovations during the ages, of which the most notable ones are those during the 18th century, who gave the Cathedral its current look.

Aside from the many chapels, each dedicated to a different saint, the most important pieces inside of it are the tombs of the Royals who ruled over Palermo and Sicily, among which is Federico II, the King responsible for making this city the cultural center of the Holy Roman Empire. \nWorth mentioning are also the chapel and painting dedicated to Santa Rosalia, the patron saint of the city, and the underground Crypts where some of the most important bishops and cardinals were buried.

I hope you brought your swimming suit, because you definitely have to try the Sicilian sea! \nAmong the many places where Palermitans go to swim, I will suggest you two location, which are different one another, and suitable for different people. \nThe first one is Mondello, a borough located between Mount Gallo and Mount Pellegrino: it\'s the beach where most people go, especially the young ones. It\'s also where the wealthiest citizens built their magnificent villas and gardens in Liberty style during the beginning of 20th century.

The other one is Sferracavallo, a fishing village just 10 minutes away from the city. \nThis is a more quiet location, and it retained the look and feel of the typical sicilian villages you could find on old postcards. \nProtip: if you go there, don\'t forget to taste the local seafood!

You can't say you have seen Palermo if you don't take a walk inside its historical markets. They are the beating heart of the city and the living example of the warmth of Sicilians. 
Created during different times in history, these crowded and colorful places show us what Palermo must have been like during its golden age, when it was the commercial hub of the whole Mediterranean Sea. 
Today are mainly populated by food vendors, but in some of them you can easily find clothes and vintage stuff at cheap prices. 
The most important ones are la Vucciria (which takes its name from butchery, since it was the main place to sell and buy meat), il Capo, and Ballarò (which name comes from and Indian word, because it was mainly a spice market).

Wherever you are, at any hour of the day, there's always a bakery, a street vendor or a pizzeria open and serving food. 
There are no tips or suggestions when it comes to eating, just look around, get in the store and ask for their specialty... there is no bad food in Palermo! 
Whether it's a full meal in a restaurant, or the greasy, fragrant street food, you will never experience something like that anywhere else. 
And of course, don't forget the amazing wines and the desserts!
